FacilityName: American Foods Group-Green Bay/East River Plus

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Commitment-Safety Approach

American Foods Group considers their employees to be their most valuable resource, their health and safety is our greatest responsibility.  As our most valuable resource, we place top priority in informing, educating, protecting, and preserving our employees as valuable members of the company.

American Foods Group's primary focus is to prevent the occurance of unforeseen industrial incidents/accidents from occuring in the work environment.

Facility Descriptions and Regulated Substance

The operations at the facility consists of the processing of beef and specialty meat cuts.  The facility employs approximately 100 employees.   The refrigeration system at the facility comprises our Process, with the regulated substance being Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3).  This is a self contained system which provides the refrigeration for the East River facility.

Ammonia Refrigeration System Description

The ammonia refrigeration system is a single stage, closed-loop system this is used to provide cooling for:  process room, temperature control, water chilling and temper water for sanitation.  A minimal amount of freezer storage is maintained at this facility.  

5-year Accident History

There have been no Anhydrous Ammonia-related incidents identified for the facility in the previous five years which resulted in significant on-site or off-site consequences (New Facility).

To accomplish the facility's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established a multi-faceted Safety Program.  The objectuives of the Safety Program are to achieve maximum efficiency and safety performance.

The facility has implemented a prevention program for the accidental release of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process Elements of the program coincide with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (Safety Process Management of Highly Hazardous Chemical, 29 CFR 1910.119); Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management P

rogram (RMP) Regulation, (Risk Managment Programs for the Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68); State of Wisconsin's Ref Code: Chapter 45, Anhydrous Ammonia Refrigeration and LP Gas Inspection Report.  The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent occurances, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fire, explosion, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Components of Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program consists of the following elements:

-Employee Participation                               -Training
-Process Safety Information                       -Contractors
-Process Hazard Analysis                          -Pre-Startup Review
-Operating Procedures                                -Mechanical Integrity
-Hot Work Program                                      -Incident Investigation
-Management of Change                             -Compliance Audits
-Preventative Maintenance                          

Emergency Response Program has been implemented at the facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to Anhydrous Ammonia spills & other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  This program has been coordinated with the Fire Department and LEPC.

The response plan includes such elements as Organizational Plan and Responsibilities, communication procedures, action plans, emergency first aid and medical treatment procedure, evacuation procedures, outside assistance, and response training.

Summary of the Worst Case Scenario and Alternative Release Scenarios

American Foods Group has diligently and proactively developed emergency response procedures to be followed in the unlikely event of a situation involving the release of anhydrous ammonia, which is commonly used in refrigeration systems in the food industry.

As required by the EPA and to minimize th

e safety of our employees and surrounding community, the company has developed a hypothetical worst case scenario.  This model involves the release of 18,000 pounds of ammonia over a 10 minute period from a vessel leak (Liquid Spill and Vaporization) inside the facility.  Using a variety of factors such as extreme and unlikely weather conditions and mitigated release, ammonia would travel a theoretical distance before dispersing.  Based upon the model, that distance could be up to 2.2 miles.  However, industry experts consider the above scenario to be unlikely for the following reasons:

-Pressure safety valves limit operating pressures in these vessels 
-Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of this vessel
-A comprehensive preventive maintenance program is in place to maintain the ongoing integrity of the vessel
-Emergency response procedures would enable highly-trained personnel to respond quickly to isolate any on-site or off-site situation.

The hypothetical alternative release scenario for this facility is described as pipe leak located in the compressor room of the facility.  This model is based upon the release of 620 lbs of ammonia (anhydrous) over a 10 minute period.  Using a variety of factors, such as extreme and unlikely weather conditions, ammonia would travel theoretical distance before dispersing.  Based upon the model, that distance could be up to .19 miles.  However, industry experts consider this hypothetical scenario to be unlikely for the following reasons:

-The weather conditions which were used for this scenario are unlikely to occur.
-Pressure safety valves limit operating pressures. 
-Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of piping.
-Preventative maintenace program in place to maintain the on going integrity.
-Emergency stop buttons located in areas outside of potential  exposure areas.

Continual Safety Updates

The faciltiy strives for continual safety improvement.  Some

areas of updates in the future shall include, continued training for new employees and contractors and working with Brown County Hazardous Response Team for emergency preparedness purposes (touring the facility and familarizing themselves with the layout and configuration of the facility and the refrigeration process).

Note:  9.1 (a): LEPC has been notified and is planning on including the facility in the written Community Emergency Response Plan.
